Straggler-Resilient Federated Learning:
Leveraging the Interplay Between Statistical Accuracy and System Heterogeneity

Amirhossein Reisizadeh , Isidoros Tziotis , Hamed Hassani ,
Aryan Mokhtari22footnotemark: 2 , Ramtin Pedarsani11footnotemark: 1 UC Santa Barbara, {reisizadeh@ucsb.edu, ramtin@ece.ucsb.edu}.The University of Texas at Austin, {isidoros_13@hotmail.com, mokhtari@austin.utexas.edu}.University of Pennsylvania, {hassani@seas.upenn.edu}.
Abstract

Federated Learning is a novel paradigm that involves learning from data samples distributed across a large network of clients while the data remains local. It is, however, known that federated learning is prone to multiple system challenges including system heterogeneity where clients have different computation and communication capabilities. Such heterogeneity in clientsâ€™ computation speeds has a negative effect on the scalability of federated learning algorithms and causes significant slow-down in their runtime due to the existence of stragglers. In this paper, we propose a novel straggler-resilient federated learning method that incorporates statistical characteristics of the clientsâ€™ data to adaptively select the clients in order to speed up the learning procedure. The key idea of our algorithm is to start the training procedure with faster nodes and gradually involve the slower nodes in the model training once the statistical accuracy of the data corresponding to the current participating nodes is reached. The proposed approach reduces the overall runtime required to achieve the statistical accuracy of data of all nodes, as the solution for each stage is close to the solution of the subsequent stage with more samples and can be used as a warm-start. Our theoretical results characterize the speedup gain in comparison to standard federated benchmarks for strongly convex objectives, and our numerical experiments also demonstrate significant speedups in wall-clock time of our straggler-resilient method compared to federated learning benchmarks.

1 Introduction

Federated learning is a distributed learning framework whose objective is to train a learning model using the data of many clients (nodes) while keeping each nodeâ€™s data localized. In contrast with central learning or learning at a data center, the federated learning architecture allows for preserving the clientsâ€™ privacy as well as reducing the communication burden caused by transmitting data to a cloud. Nevertheless, as we move towards deploying federated learning in practice, it is becoming apparent that several major challenges still remain and the existing frameworks need to be rethought to address them. Important among these challenges is system (device) heterogeneity due to existence of straggling nodes â€“ slow nodes with low computational capability â€“ that significantly slow down the model training (Li etÂ al., 2019a, ; Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2019).

In this paper, we focus on system heterogeneity in federated learning frameworks and we leverage the interplay between statistical accuracy and system heterogeneity to design a straggler-resilient federated learning method that carefully and adaptively selects a subset of available nodes in each round of training. A typical federated learning network consists of thousands of devices with a wide range of computational, communication, battery power, and storage characteristics. Hence, deploying traditional federated learning algorithms such as FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017) on such a highly heterogeneous cluster of devices results in significant and unexpected delays due to existence of slow clients or stragglers. In most of such algorithms, all the available clients participate in the model training â€“regardless of their computational capabilities. Consequently, in each communication round of such methods, the server has to wait for the slowest node to complete its local updates and upload its local model which significantly slows down the training process.

In this work, we aim to mitigate the effect of stragglers in federated learning frameworks based on an adaptive node participation approach in which clients are selected to participate in different stages of the training according to their computation speed. We call our straggler-resilient proposal a Federated Learning method with Adaptive Node Participation algorithm or FLANP. The key idea of this scheme is to start the model training procedure with only a few clients which are the fastest among all the nodes. These participating clients continue to train their shared models while interacting with the parameter server. Note that since the server waits only for the participating nodes, it takes a short time for the participating (and fast) clients to promptly train a shared model. This model is, however, not accurate as it is trained over only a fraction of samples. We now increase the number of participating clients and include the next fastest subset of nonparticipating nodes in the training. Note that the model trained from the previous stage can be a warm-start initialization for the current stage.

To discuss our main idea more precisely, consider a federated network of Nğ‘N available nodes each storing sğ‘ s data samples and suppose that we start the learning procedure with only mğ‘šm clients. Once we solve the empirical risk minimization (ERM) problem corresponding to mÃ—sğ‘šğ‘ m\times s samples of these nodes up to its statistical accuracy, we geometrically increase the number of participating nodes to n=Î±â€‹mğ‘›ğ›¼ğ‘šn=\alpha m where Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1, by adding the next nâˆ’mğ‘›ğ‘šn-m fastest clients in the network. By doing so, the new ERM problem that we aim to solve contains the samples from the previous stage as well as the samples of the newly participating nodes. Also, the solution for the ERM problem at the previous stage (with mğ‘šm clients) could be used as a warm-start for the ERM problem at the current stage with n=Î±â€‹mğ‘›ğ›¼ğ‘šn=\alpha m nodesâ€“This is due to the fact that all samples are drawn from a common distribution, and as a result, the optimal solution of the ERM problem with less samples is not far from the optimal solution of the ERM problems with more samples, as long as the larger set contains the smaller set.

In the proposed FLANP algorithm, as time progresses, we gradually increase the number of participating clients until we reach the full training set and all clients are involved. Note that in this procedure the slower clients are only used towards the end of the learning process, where the model is already close to the optimal model of the aggregate loss. Another essential observation is that since the model trained in previous rounds already has a reasonable statistical accuracy and this model serves as the initial point of the next round of the iterative algorithm, the slower nodes are only needed to contribute in the final rounds of training, leading to a smaller wall-clock time. This is in contrast with having all nodes participate in training from the beginning, which leads to computation time of each round being determined by the slowest node. In this paper, we formally characterize the gain obtained by using the proposed adaptive node participation scheme compared to the case that all available nodes contribute to training at each round. Next, we state a summary of our main contributions:

  • â€¢

    We present a straggler-resilient federated learning meta-algorithm that leverages the interplay between statistical accuracy and device heterogeneity by adaptively activating heterogeneous clients.

  • â€¢

    We specify the proposed meta-algorithm with a federated learning subroutine and present its optimization guarantees for strongly convex risks. Moreover, we characterize the wall-clock time of the proposed straggler-resilient scheme and demonstrate analytically that it achieves up to ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(Nâ€‹s))ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ {\mathcal{O}}(\log(Ns)) speedup gain compared to standard federated benchmarks.

  • â€¢

    Our numerical results show that our framework significantly improves the wall-clock time compared to federated learning benchmarks â€“with either full or partial node participationâ€“ for both convex and non-convex risks.

Related Work.

System (device) heterogeneity challenge, which refers to the case that clients have different computational, communication and storage characteristics, has been studied in the literature. Asynchronous methods have demonstrated significant improvements in distributed data centers, however, such methods are less desirable in federated learning frameworks as they rely on bounded staleness of slow clients (Stich,, 2019; Xie etÂ al.,, 2019). The active sampling approach is another direction in which the server aims for aggregating as many local updates as possible within a predefined time span (Nishio and Yonetani,, 2019). More recently, Wang etÂ al., (2020) proposed a normalized averaging method to mitigate stragglers in federated systems and the objective inconsistency due to mismatch in clientsâ€™ local updates. Deadline-based computation has also been proposed to mitigate stragglers in decentralized training (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019b, ). In a different yet related direction, various federated learning algorithms have been studied to address the heterogeneity in clientsâ€™ data distributions (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2019; Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2020; Li etÂ al.,, 2018; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020a, ; Mohri etÂ al.,, 2019; Reddi etÂ al.,, 2020).

The idea of adaptive sample size training in which we solve a sequence of geometrically increasing ERM problems has been used previously for solving large-scale ERM problems. In particular, it has been shown that this scheme significantly improves the overall computational complexity of both first-order (Mokhtari and Ribeiro,, 2017; Mokhtari etÂ al.,, 2019) and second-order (Mokhtari etÂ al.,, 2016; Eisen etÂ al.,, 2018; Jahani etÂ al.,, 2020) methods for achieving the statistical accuracy of the full training set. In this paper, we exploit this idea to develop FLANP for a completely different setting where we aim to address the issue of device heterogeneity in federated learning.

As mentioned earlier, FLANP is a general meta-algorithm that can be employed with any choice of federated learning subroutine such as the celebrated FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017) and its variants (Wang and Joshi, 2018b, ; Li etÂ al., 2019b, ; Huo etÂ al.,, 2020; Pathak and Wainwright,, 2020; Malinovsky etÂ al.,, 2020; Wang etÂ al.,, 2019). Convergence properties of such methods have also been extensively studied in the literature (Zhou and Cong,, 2017; Haddadpour and Mahdavi,, 2019; Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2019; Bayoumi etÂ al.,, 2020; Stich and Karimireddy,, 2019; Wang and Joshi, 2018a, ; Koloskova etÂ al.,, 2020; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020b, ; Liang etÂ al.,, 2019). In this paper, we only showcase the gain obtained by combining FLANP and FedGATE proposed in (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2020).

We also note that the described setup is slightly different from the prior work on data homogeneous and data heterogeneous settings. To be more precise, in the standard data homogeneous settings the samples of all nodes are drawn according to a common distribution, which is similar to our setup. However, in homogeneous settings, it is also assumed that each node can draw new i.i.d. samples at each round, which is different from our setting where all samples are selected at the first round. Indeed, this difference is crucial, as in the described homogeneous settings the samples used at each round are independent and the local gradient direction of each node is an unbiased estimator of the aggregate loss, but in our setting we cannot guarantee that the samples used at each round are independent and more importantly we cannot ensure that the local gradient direction âˆ‡Liâˆ‡superscriptğ¿ğ‘–\nabla L^{i} is an unbiased estimator for the aggregate loss gradient âˆ‡LNâˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘\nabla L_{N}. Considering this observation, our setup might be closer to the data heterogeneous setting, since local gradients are not aligned with each other (in expectation). However, our setup is less general compared to a data heterogeneous setting, as we still assume that the given samples are all drawn from a common distribution, unlike the data heterogeneous setting where nodes could have arbitrary different data distributions.

Statistical Accuracy. The difference of expected and empirical risks Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’Lâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğ’˜ğ¿ğ’˜L_{n}(\bm{w})-L(\bm{w}) is referred to as the estimation error and can be bounded by a function of the sample size. In particular, since Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğ’˜L_{n}(\bm{w}) captures nâ€‹sğ‘›ğ‘ ns samples, we assume that there exists a constant Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ V_{ns} bounding the estimation error with high probability,

supğ’˜|Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’Lâ€‹(ğ’˜)|â‰¤Vnâ€‹s,w.h.p.subscriptsupremumğ’˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘›ğ’˜ğ¿ğ’˜subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ w.h.p.\displaystyle\sup_{\bm{w}}|L_{n}(\bm{w})-L(\bm{w})|\leq V_{ns},\quad\text{w.h.p.}

The estimation error Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ V_{ns} has been deeply studied in the statistical learning literature (Vapnik,, 2013; Bousquet,, 2002). In particular, it has been shown that for strongly convex functions the estimation error is proportional to the inverse of sample size (Bartlett etÂ al.,, 2006; Frostig etÂ al.,, 2015). In this work, we also assume that Vnâ€‹s=cnâ€‹ssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘ V_{ns}=\frac{c}{ns} for a constant cğ‘c. Note that for the loss function Lnsubscriptğ¿ğ‘›L_{n} once we find a point ğ’˜~~ğ’˜\tilde{\bm{w}} that has an optimization error of Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ V_{ns}, i.e., Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜~)âˆ’Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜nâˆ—)â‰¤Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ¿ğ‘›~ğ’˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ L_{n}(\tilde{\bm{w}})-L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}^{*})\leq V_{ns}, there is no gain in improving the optimization error as the overall error with respect to the expected risk Lğ¿L would not improve. Hence, when we find a point ğ’˜~~ğ’˜\tilde{\bm{w}} such that Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜~)âˆ’Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜nâˆ—)â‰¤Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ¿ğ‘›~ğ’˜subscriptğ¿ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ L_{n}(\tilde{\bm{w}})-L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}^{*})\leq V_{ns}, we state that it has reached the statistical accuracy of Lnsubscriptğ¿ğ‘›L_{n}. Our goal is to find a solution ğ’˜Nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘\bm{w}_{N} that is within the statistical accuracy of the ERM problem corresponding to the full training set defined in (2).

System Heterogeneity Model. As mentioned earlier, federated clients attribute a wide range of computational powers leading to significantly different processing time for a fixed computing task such as gradient computation and local model update. To be more specific, for each node iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[N], we let Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} denote the (expected) time to compute one local model update. The time for such update is mostly determined by the computation time of a fixed batch-size stochastic gradient of the local empirical risk Liâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ’˜L_{i}(\bm{w}). Clearly, larger Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} corresponds to slower clients or stragglers. Without loss of generality, we assume that the nodes are sorted from faster to slower, that is, T1â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤TNsubscriptğ‘‡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{1}\leq\cdots\leq T_{N} with node 111 and Nğ‘N respectively identifying the fastest and slowest nodes in the network.

3 Adaptive Node Participation Approach

Several federated learning algorithms have been proposed to solve the ERM problem in (2) such as FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017), FedProx (Li etÂ al.,, 2018), SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2019), DIANA (Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2019), FedGATE (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2020), etc. These methods consist of many rounds of local computations by the local clients and communication with the parameter server. Alas, in all such approaches, all the available nodes in the network â€“regardless of their computational capabilitiesâ€“ contribute to model learning throughout the entire procedure. As explained in the previous section, federated clients operate in a wide range of computational characteristics, and therefore, the parameter server has to wait for the slowest node in each communication round to complete its local computation task. All in all, the slowest nodes (stragglers) determine the overall wall-clock time of the such federated algorithms which causes significant slow-down.

In this section, we first describe our proposed approach to mitigate stragglers in federated learning settings and lay out the rational behind our method. Our proposal, FLANP, is essentially a meta-algorithm that can be specified with the choice of any particular federated learning subroutine. The rest of the section focuses on a particular case of the proposed FLANP algorithm where the federated learning subroutine is picked to be FedGATE proposed by Haddadpour etÂ al., (2020).

3.1 FLANP: A Straggler-Resilient Federated Learning Meta-Algorithm

Consider the federated learning setting described in Section 2 consisting of Nğ‘N available nodes with different computation times T1â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤TNsubscriptğ‘‡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{1}\leq\cdots\leq T_{N}. Our proposal to address the device heterogeneity and mitigate the stragglers is as follows. We start off the learning procedure with the n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} fastest nodes, that are nodes {1,2,â‹¯,n0}12â‹¯subscriptğ‘›0\{1,2,\cdots,n_{0}\}, and n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} is much smaller than the total number of available nodes Nğ‘N. Using Federated_Solver which is a federated learning subroutine of choice, e.g., FedAvg or FedGATE, the set of n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} participating nodes proceed to minimize the empirical risk corresponding to their data points, which we denote by Ln0â€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘›0ğ’˜L_{n_{0}}(\bm{w}) as defined in (1). This continues until the n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} nodes reach their corresponding statistical accuracy, that is, they reach a global model ğ’˜n0subscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{n_{0}} such that Ln0â€‹(ğ’˜n0)âˆ’Ln0â€‹(ğ’˜n0âˆ—)â‰¤Vn0â€‹ssubscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ¿subscriptğ‘›0superscriptsubscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘‰subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘ L_{n_{0}}(\bm{w}_{n_{0}})-L_{n_{0}}(\bm{w}_{n_{0}}^{*})\leq V_{n_{0}s}. Note that at this stage the server has to wait only for the slowest client among the participating ones, i.e., node n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0}, which is potentially much faster than the networkâ€™s slowest node Nğ‘N.

Per our discussion in Section 2, a more accurate solution than ğ’˜n0subscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{n_{0}} would not help improving the optimality gap. Therefore, once statistical accuracy is achieved, the procedure is terminated and we increase the number of participating nodes from n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} to 2â€‹n02subscriptğ‘›02n_{0}, implying that nodes {1,2,â‹¯,2â€‹n0}12â‹¯2subscriptğ‘›0\{1,2,\cdots,2n_{0}\} now participate in improving the global model. Using the model learned form the previous stage ğ’˜n0subscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{n_{0}} as the initial model, the nodes in {1,2,â‹¯,2â€‹n0}12â‹¯2subscriptğ‘›0\{1,2,\cdots,2n_{0}\} employ the solver Federated_Solver and continue the learning procedure to reach a global model ğ’˜2â€‹n0subscriptğ’˜2subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{2n_{0}} within their corresponding statistical accuracy. That is, the global model ğ’˜2â€‹n0subscriptğ’˜2subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{2n_{0}} satisfies L2â€‹n0â€‹(ğ’˜2â€‹n0)âˆ’L2â€‹n0â€‹(ğ’˜2â€‹n0âˆ—)â‰¤V2â€‹n0â€‹ssubscriptğ¿2subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ’˜2subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ¿2subscriptğ‘›0superscriptsubscriptğ’˜2subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘ L_{2n_{0}}(\bm{w}_{2n_{0}})-L_{2n_{0}}(\bm{w}_{2n_{0}}^{*})\leq V_{2n_{0}s}. In this stage with 2â€‹n02subscriptğ‘›02n_{0} participating nodes, the computation delay is determined by the slowest participating node, i.e., node 2â€‹n02subscriptğ‘›02n_{0}, which is slower than the previous stage with n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} participating nodes, but faster than the networkâ€™s slowest node, Nğ‘N. The procedure of geometrically increasing the number of participating nodes continues till the set of participating nodes contains all the available Nğ‘N nodes and nodes find the final global model ğ’˜Nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘\bm{w}_{N} within the statistical accuracy of the global loss function LNâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ’˜L_{N}(\bm{w}). Algorithm 1 summarises the straggler-resilient meta-algorithm described above.

From a high-level perspective, Algorithm 1 exploits the faster nodes in the beginning of the learning procedure to promptly reach a global model withing their statistical accuracy. By doing so, the parameter server avoids waiting for the slow nodes to complete their local updates; however, the optimality gap of such models are relatively large since only a fraction of data samples have contributed in the global model. By gradually increasing the number of participating nodes and activating slower nodes, the quality of the global model improves while the synchronous computation slows down due to slower nodes. The key point is that slower nodes join the learning process towards the end of process.

The criterion in Algorithm 1, that is Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜n)âˆ’Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜nâˆ—)>Vnâ€‹ssubscriptğ¿ğ‘›subscriptğ’˜ğ‘›subscriptğ¿ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n})-L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}^{*})>V_{ns}, verifies that the current global model satisfies the statistical accuracy corresponding to nğ‘›n participating nodes {1,â‹¯,n}1â‹¯ğ‘›\{1,\cdots,n\}. This condition, however, is not easy to check since nodes do not have access to the optimal solution ğ’˜nâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\bm{w}_{n}^{*}. A sufficient and computationally feasible criterion is to check if â€–âˆ‡Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜n)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹Î¼â€‹Vnâ€‹ssuperscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘›subscriptğ’˜ğ‘›22ğœ‡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ \|\nabla L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n})\|^{2}\leq 2\mu V_{ns}, when the loss function â„“â„“\ell is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex.

Now consider a subset of mğ‘šm participating nodes which we denote by ğ’©mâŠ†[N]subscriptğ’©ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘{\mathcal{N}}_{m}\subseteq[N] and assume that they have reached their statistical accuracy, i.e., model ğ’˜mâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}^{*}_{m} such that Lmâ€‹(ğ’˜m)âˆ’Lmâ€‹(ğ’˜mâˆ—)â‰¤Vmâ€‹ssubscriptğ¿ğ‘šsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ¿ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘šğ‘ L_{m}(\bm{w}_{m})-L_{m}(\bm{w}_{m}^{*})\leq V_{ms}. Next proposition characterizes the initial suboptimality when the model ğ’˜mâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}^{*}_{m} is used as the initial warm-start model for a larger set of participating nodes ğ’©nsubscriptğ’©ğ‘›{\mathcal{N}}_{n} where ğ’©mâŠ†ğ’©nsubscriptğ’©ğ‘šsubscriptğ’©ğ‘›{\mathcal{N}}_{m}\subseteq{\mathcal{N}}_{n}.

Proposition 1

Consider two subsets of nodes ğ’©mâŠ†ğ’©nsubscriptğ’©ğ‘šsubscriptğ’©ğ‘›{\mathcal{N}}_{m}\subseteq{\mathcal{N}}_{n} and assume that model ğ°msubscriptğ°ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} attains the statistical accuracy for the empirical risk associated with nodes in ğ’©msubscriptğ’©ğ‘š{\mathcal{N}}_{m}, that is, â€–âˆ‡Lmâ€‹(ğ°m)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹Î¼â€‹Vmâ€‹ssuperscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘šsubscriptğ°ğ‘š22ğœ‡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘šğ‘ \|\nabla L_{m}(\bm{w}_{m})\|^{2}\leq 2\mu V_{ms} where the loss function â„“â„“\ell is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex. Proposition 1 demonstrates that a model attaining the statistical accuracy for mğ‘šm nodes in ğ’©msubscriptğ’©ğ‘š{\mathcal{N}}_{m} can be used as an initial warmup model for the ERM corresponding to nğ‘›n nodes in ğ’©nsubscriptğ’©ğ‘›{\mathcal{N}}_{n} which includes ğ’©msubscriptğ’©ğ‘š{\mathcal{N}}_{m}. As the proposed meta-algorithm FLANP in AlgorithmÂ 1 provides a general mechanism to mitigate stragglers in federated settings, one needs to specify the inner optimization subroutine Federated_Solver to quantify the speedup of the proposed approach. This subroutine may be any federated learning algorithm (with possible adjustments). Next, we pick the subroutine in Algorithm 1 to be FedGATE (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2020).

3.2 FLANP via FedGATE

We now focus on a specific instance of the meta-algorithm proposed in Algorithm 1 where the subroutine Federated_Solver is set to be FedGATE, a federated learning algorithm that employs gradient tracking variables to provide tight convergence guarantees for nodes with heterogeneous data distributions. One reason that we use FedGATE as a subroutine is that it can handle the case that local gradients are not an unbiased estimator of the global loss gradient, which is the case in our setting. Algorithm 2 demonstrates how the adaptive node participation approach in FLANP is adopted to mitigate straggler delays in FedGATE.

We begin the first stage of AlgorithmÂ 2 with activating the n=n0ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›0n=n_{0} fastest nodes {1,â‹¯,n0}1â‹¯subscriptğ‘›0\{1,\cdots,n_{0}\} and initialize them with an arbitrary global model ğ’˜n0subscriptğ’˜subscriptğ‘›0\bm{w}_{n_{0}}. We also reset the gradient tracking variables Î´i(0)subscriptsuperscriptğ›¿0ğ‘–\delta^{(0)}_{i} to be zero for all participating nodes at the beginning of each stage. Variables Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i} aim to correct the directions of local updates at node iğ‘–i by tracking the difference of local stochastic gradients âˆ‡~â€‹Li~âˆ‡superscriptğ¿ğ‘–\widetilde{\nabla}L^{i} and global gradients âˆ‡Lnâˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘›\nabla L_{n} such that directions disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i} closely follow the correct global gradient direction. After Ï„nsubscriptğœğ‘›\tau_{n} iterations of local updates at any participating node in round rğ‘Ÿr, accumulations of local gradients Î”i(r)subscriptsuperscriptÎ”ğ‘Ÿğ‘–\Delta^{(r)}_{i} are uploaded to the server where it updates the average Î”(r)superscriptÎ”ğ‘Ÿ\Delta^{(r)} and the global model ğ’˜nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\bm{w}_{n} using two stepsizes Î·n,Î³nsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘›subscriptğ›¾ğ‘›\eta_{n},\gamma_{n}. Note that the stepsizes Î·n,Î³nsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘›subscriptğ›¾ğ‘›\eta_{n},\gamma_{n} are fixed throughout each stage with nğ‘›n participating nodes but vary for different stages as nğ‘›n increases. After updating the global model ğ’˜nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\bm{w}_{n} at the end of each round, participating nodes upload their local gradients âˆ‡Liâ€‹(ğ’˜n)âˆ‡superscriptğ¿ğ‘–subscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\nabla L^{i}(\bm{w}_{n}) such that the server aggregates and computes the global gradient âˆ‡Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜n)âˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘›subscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\nabla L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}) and checks whether the condition â€–âˆ‡Lnâ€‹(ğ’˜n)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹Î¼â€‹Vnâ€‹ssuperscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¿ğ‘›subscriptğ’˜ğ‘›22ğœ‡subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ \|\nabla L_{n}(\bm{w}_{n})\|^{2}\leq 2\mu V_{ns} is satisfied. After Rnsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘›R_{n} rounds of communications, this condition is satisfied and the set of nğ‘›n participating nodes reach the global model ğ’˜nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\bm{w}_{n} within their statistical accuracy. Therefore, we augment the set of participating nodes (from faster to slower ones) from {1,â‹¯,n}1â‹¯ğ‘›\{1,\cdots,n\} to {1,â‹¯,2â€‹n}1â‹¯2ğ‘›\{1,\cdots,2n\} leading to a new stage. The above procedure continues until the set of participating nodes contains all Nğ‘N available nodes.

4 Theoretical Results

In this section, we provide rigorous analysis for the proposed straggler-resilient FLANP scheme outlined in Algorithm 2, which employs FedGATE as its subroutine. We first characterize optimization guarantees of Algorithm 2. Using such results, we derive the expected runtime of our proposed algorithm and the speedup gain it provides compared to naive methods.

4.1 Optimization Guarantees

In this section, we aim to characterize the required communication and computation for solving each subproblem. To be more precise, consider the case that we are given a model ğ’˜msubscriptğ’˜ğ‘š\bm{w}_{m} which is within the statistical accuracy of Lmsubscriptğ¿ğ‘šL_{m} corresponding to mğ‘šm fastest nodes, and the goal is to find a new model ğ’˜nsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘›\bm{w}_{n} that is within the statistical accuracy of Lnsubscriptğ¿ğ‘›L_{n} corresponding to nğ‘›n fastest nodes, where n=2â€‹mğ‘›2ğ‘šn=2m. To analyze this procedure, we need to quantify three parameters: the choice of stepsizes Î·n,Î³nsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘›subscriptğ›¾ğ‘›\eta_{n},\gamma_{n}, the number of local updates Ï„nsubscriptğœğ‘›\tau_{n} at each participating node, and the number of communication rounds with the server Rnsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘›R_{n}. Note that for all of these parameters we use the index nğ‘›n as they refer to the case that nğ‘›n nodes participate in learning. Before stating our result, we first formally state our assumptions.

4.2 Wall-Clock Time Analysis

We have thus far established convergence properties of Algorithm 2 and precisely derived its parameters. It is, however, equally important to show that it provably mitigates stragglers in a federated learning framework and hence speeds up the overall wall-clock time. In the following, we first characterize the running time of Algorithm 2 and then compare it with the one for straggler-prone FedGATE benchmarks.

Proposition 2

The average runtime of Algorithm 2 to reach the overall statistical accuracy of the ERM problem corresponding to all nodes (defined in (2)) is

The result in Proposition 2 further demonstrates how the adaptive node participation approach incorporates faster nodes in order to save in the overall wall-clock time. To quantify the speedup gain provided by the proposed straggler-resilient method, we need to characterize the wall-clock time for the non-adaptive benchmark FedGATE. Note that in this benchmark, all the Nğ‘N available nodes are participating in the training process from the beginning.

To establish a more concrete speedup gain for the straggler-resilient method, we need to consider a computation time model for the federated clients. Random exponential time model has been widely used to capture the computation delay for distributed clusters (Lee etÂ al.,, 2017; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2019a, ). In the next theorem, we assume that node computation times are independent realizations of an exponential random variable and characterize the speedup gain of the resilient Algorithm 2 compared to the benchmark FedGATE.

Theorem 2

The result in Theorem 2 establishes a ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(Nâ€‹s))ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ {\mathcal{O}}(\log(Ns)) speedup gain for our proposed straggler-resilient method compared to its non-adaptive and straggler-prone benchmark where the clientsâ€™ computation times are drawn from a random exponential time model.

We have so far considered heterogeneous federated clients with potentially well-spread computation speeds and demonstrated the speedup gain obtained by adaptive node participation method, particularly in Theorem 2. However, this method provides provable speedups even for homogeneous federated clients with identical speeds, i.e. T1=â‹¯=TNsubscriptğ‘‡1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘T_{1}=\cdots=T_{N}. Comparing the expected runtimes in (5) yields that FLANP in Algorithm 2 slashes the expected wall-clock time of FedGATE by a factor logâ¡(Nâ€‹s)/logâ¡(N)ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘\log(Ns)/\log(N). This observation demonstrates that the adaptive node participation approach results in two different speedup gains; (iğ‘–i) leveraging faster nodes to speedup the learning, and (iâ€‹iğ‘–ğ‘–ii) adaptively increase the effective sample size by participating more clients.

Remark 1

The result in this section shows that the proposed adaptive node participation framework FLANP is able to make the FedGATE algorithm robust against stragglers and reduce its runtime when we face a device heterogeneous setting. We would like to reiterate that FLANP is a meta-procedure that can be used for any federated learning solver other than FedGATE to make it resilient against straggling nodes in the network.

5 Numerical Experiments

We conduct various numerical experiments for convex and nonconvex risks and evaluate the performance of the proposed method versus other benchmarks.

Benchmarks. Bellow is a brief description for multiple federated learning benchmarks that we use to compare with the proposed FLANP in Algorithm 2. Note that in all these benchmarks all the available Nğ‘N nodes participate in the training process.

  • â€¢

    FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017). Nodes update their local model using a simple SGD rule for Ï„ğœ\tau local iterations before uploading to the server.

  • â€¢

    FedGATE (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2020). This is the subroutine used in Algorithm 2. Here we consider it as a benchmark running with all the available Nğ‘N nodes with model update rule similar to the subroutine in Algorithm 2.

  • â€¢

    FedNova (Wang etÂ al.,, 2020). In each round, each node iğ‘–i updates its local model for Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i} iterations where Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}s vary across the nodes. To mitigate the heterogeneity in Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}s, the parameter server aggregates normalized updates (w.r.t. Ï„isubscriptğœğ‘–\tau_{i}) from the clients and updates the global model.

We numerically evaluate the performance of FLANP with such benchmarks both with respect to communication rounds and wall-clock time. We examine FLANP against the benchmarks under both full and partial node participation scenarios and highlight its practicality.

5.1 Uniform computation speeds

Data and Network. We use three main datasets for different problems: MNIST (60,0006000060,000 training, 10,0001000010,000 test samples), CIFAR10 (50,0005000050,000 training, 10,0001000010,000 test samples) and synthetic (10,0001000010,000 samples) datasets. To implement our algorithm, we employ a federated network of Nâˆˆ{20,50,100}ğ‘2050100N\in\{20,50,100\} heterogeneous clients and in order to model the device heterogeneity, we realize and then fix the computation speed of each node iğ‘–i, i.e. Tisubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–T_{i} from the interval [50,500]50500[50,500] uniformly at random.

Logistic Regression. We use the MNIST dataset to learn a multi-class logistic regression model. In a network of N=50ğ‘50N=50 nodes, each client stores s=1200ğ‘ 1200s=1200 samples from the MNIST dataset. As demonstrated in Figure 2 (left), FLANP is slightly outperformed by FedGATE at the initial rounds. This is however expected as FLANP starts with only a fraction of nodes participating which leads to less accurate models. With respect to wall-clock time however, FLANP outperforms both FedAvg and FedGATE benchmarks due to the fact that the initial participating nodes are indeed the fastest ones. As Figure 2 (right) shows, the adaptive node participation approach leads FLANP to speedup gains of up to 2.1Ã—2.1\times compared to FedGATE.

Linear Regression. We train a linear regression model over a synthetic dataset with 10,0001000010,000 samples distributed across N=100ğ‘100N=100 heterogeneous nodes. Figure 2 demonstrates convergence of the sub-optimality error of global models â€–ğ’˜tâˆ’ğ’˜âˆ—â€–normsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡superscriptğ’˜\|\bm{w}_{t}-\bm{w}^{*}\| for three methods FLANP, FedGATE and FedAvg. Similar to Figure 2, we observe the same behavior for the optimality gap versus communication round and wall-clock time in Figure 2 where FLANP manages to speed up the training time by 10Ã—10\times compared to non-adaptive FedGATE.

Neural Network Training. We train a fully connected neural network with two hidden layers with 128128128 and 646464 neurons and compare with three other benchmarks including FedNova which is stragglers-resilient federated algorithm. We conduct two sets of experiments over MNIST and CIFAR10 datasets on a network of N=20ğ‘20N=20 clients. Figures 4 and 4 demonstrate that FLANP significantly accelerates the training by up to 3Ã—3\times and 4Ã—4\times compared to FedNova. We note that in order to have a fair comparison, the stepsize in all methods is set to Î·=0.05ğœ‚0.05\eta=0.05 for MNIST and Î·=0.02ğœ‚0.02\eta=0.02 for CIFAR10 and Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1.

5.2 Random exponential computation speeds

We conduct another set of experiments using the same setup described in Section 5.1, however, we here pick the clientsâ€™ computation speed to be i.i.d. random exponential variables which is more consistent with the setup of theorem 2. We train a fully connected neural network with two hidden layers with 128128128 and 646464 neurons on MNIST dataset and compare with the same benchmarks FedAvg, FedGATE and FedNova as demonstrate in Figure 5.

5.3 Comparison with partial node participation methods

In this section, we have been comparing the FLANP method with federated benchmarks in which all of the available nodes participate in training in every round. To demonstrate the resiliency of FLANP to partial node participation methods, we consider two different scenarios. First, we compare the wall-clock time of a neural network training of FLANP with partial node participation FedGATE in which only kğ‘˜k out of N=50ğ‘50N=50 nodes are randomly picked and participate in each round. As demonstrated in Figure 6(6(a)), FLANP is significantly faster than FedGATE with partial node participation. Second, we consider the case that the kğ‘˜k participating nodes are not randomly picked; rather are the fastest clients. As shown in Figure 6(6(b)), although partial participation methods with kğ‘˜k fastest nodes begin to outperform FLANP towards the end of the training, they suffer from higher training error saturation as the data samples of only kğ‘˜k nodes contribute in the learned model and hence the final model is significantly inaccurate.

5.4 Effect of Nğ‘N and sğ‘ s and the practicality of FLANP

In this section, we particularly focus on the setting described in Theorem 2 and examine the effect of parameters Nğ‘N and sğ‘ s on the ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(Nâ€‹s))ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ {\mathcal{O}}(\log(Ns)) gain established in Theorem 2. We set the nodesâ€™ computation speeds to be i.i.d. random exponential variables and run two federated algorithms, FLANP and FedGATE. Figure 7 demonstrates the running time of the two algorithms for a linear regression problem with synthetic data. In these plots, the number of clients is fixed to be N=50ğ‘50N=50 while we increase the number of data samples per node sâˆˆ{20,200,2000}ğ‘ 202002000s\in\{20,200,2000\}. Moreover, Table 2 shows the individual running time for FLANP and FedGATE methods and the respective ratio corresponding to each case sâˆˆ{20,200,2000}ğ‘ 202002000s\in\{20,200,2000\}. Next, we conduct experiments with the same setup to examine the effect of Nğ‘N on the speedup gain ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡(Nâ€‹s))ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ {\mathcal{O}}(\log(Ns)) established in Theorem 2. Figure 8 and Table 2 demonstrate the running times and the speedup gains for FLANP and FedGATE. These sets of experiments further illustrate that increasing either the number of clients (i.e. larger device heterogeneity) or the number of data samples per node results in faster training time for the proposed FLANP method.

Lastly, we highlight a point regarding the knowledge of constant parameters Î¼,c,Vnâ€‹sğœ‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›ğ‘ \mu,c,V_{ns} in Algorithm 2 and the practicality of FLANP. Although such parameters need to be known in order to run FLANP, we note that from the practical point of view, there are several heuristic approaches to handle such issue. We conducted an experiment in which none of the constants are assumed to be known; rather, we heuristically tune the threshold for each phase transition (i.e. doubling the nodes) by monitoring the norm of the global gradient and successively halving the threshold. As shown in Figure 9, the performance of such heuristic methods is indeed close to FLANP which highlights its practicality.

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 2

ğ”¼â€‹[TFLANP]=RFLANPâ€‹Ï„FLANPâ€‹âˆ‘i=n0,â€‰2â€‹n0,â€‰4â€‹n0,â‹¯,NTi=18â€‹logâ¡(6)câ€‹Îºâ€‹sâ€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(Tn0+T2â€‹n0+â‹¯+TN),ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘‡FLANPsubscriptğ‘…FLANPsubscriptğœFLANPsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘›02subscriptğ‘›04subscriptğ‘›0â‹¯ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘–186ğ‘ğœ…ğ‘ superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘‡2subscriptğ‘›0â‹¯subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[T_{\texttt{FLANP}}]=R_{\texttt{FLANP}}\,\tau_{\texttt{FLANP}}\sum_{i\,=\,n_{0},\,2n_{0},\,4n_{0},\cdots,\,N}T_{i}=\frac{18\log(6)}{c}\kappa s\sigma^{2}\left(T_{n_{0}}+T_{2n_{0}}+\cdots+T_{N}\right), (72)
